having me today I'm going to be talking about a project that I worked on while I was at
Netflix I'm not currently there so this talk does not represent the company this is my own personal story
and I'm going to tell this story in two parts the first part is about how data
scientists at Netflix struggled to get their machine learning models into production and how meta flow helped them
become far more productive and the second part of the story is about the team that built metaflow
I want to talk about how they made Metal Flow a success and what I believe is the
single most important factor that led to that success if you are interested in improving how
you build products this portion of the talk will be for you
a brief history of my time at Netflix I've actually had two first days there
the first one was back in 2008 when Netflix was a us-based DVD by mail
subscription company and they have this brand new feature that allowed you to instantly watch a subset of that content
I was hired to work on that feature ten years later when I returned to
Netflix that feature was the product Netflix had become a global subscription
streaming service and it had over a hundred million members
but getting back to 2008 I was very much in this Paradigm that I will call
traditional software as an engineer my job was to build a
system that was valuable to the business and I needed to make sure that that system ran reliably without human
supervision and produced correct results that system at the time happened to be
the services behind the Netflix play button that did everything between movie
metadata to DRM licensing I'll say it was an exciting few years to
be there I got to build the first generation streaming service launch on
the PlayStation 3 and also launch in over 50 countries and to be honest by 2012 when Netflix
was starting to produce original content I concluded that all of the interesting
technical problems had been solved and it was time to move on and do other
things so I left for a few years to do some startups but lo and behold when I came
back in 2018 I realized that I was dead wrong
in those intervening years Netflix's investment in machine learning had expanded far beyond what you usually
think of when you think Netflix plus machine learning which is the personalized member home page
in those years the content buying team's budget had increased to over 12 billion
dollars and they wanted their decisions to be informed by data
in particular there were machine learning models that helped them program the catalog mix like series versus films
scripted versus unscripted and there were other models that helped them predict hey if I put a specific title on
the service what might be the audience size and Netflix had also spun up a studio
function that was producing content at a rate that no traditional Studio had ever
done they were doing over a hundred concurrent Productions so traditional
methods were no longer applicable so machine learning made its way all the way from pre-production helping sift
through all images of scouting locations to try to make that process more efficient all the way to helping
creatives who were doing things like editing sift through large libraries of
video content to get exactly the clip they needed at exactly the right time
and there were other facets of machine learning in the Netflix product Netflix had built a CDN and there needed to be
an algorithm to Cache the content on the CDN Edge caches we had another machine
learning application but who was doing all of this machine
learning well there was a brand new team of data scientists and how did they do
it well they grabbed a shovel and they did it all from scratch which meant they
had to navigate this complex Netflix ecosystem of infrastructure
and they realized that most of their time was spent not on machine learning modeling but on infrastructure
and so they practically begged engineering please form a team to solve
our infrastructure problems and that's when I came back in 2018 to lead machine
learning infrastructure so coming back I was in an entirely different paradigm
I'll call it ml-powered software there's several more moving parts that
make ml powered software more complex than traditional software
you still have the valuable system but now you have a machine learning model
that has to plug into that system and you have data feeding into that model
oh and by the way there's a whole new group of humans that need to interact and deploy with that system so we have a
team of data scientists to support and yet as an engineering team we still
had the job of making sure that this whole system runs reliably without supervision and produces correct
results now the Netflix problem was actually even more complicated than this
we didn't just have to solve this for one ml application we actually needed to
solve this for many many applications across a variety of business domains and
different machine learning modeling techniques so as an engineering team you know we
had our hands full we did not get the budget from Reed Hastings to keep hiring more
infrastructure Engineers for every data science project we had to find some really smart ways to
Leverage The commonalities across all these products and build a true platform
infrastructure that was going to support them so I want to share with you what were
some of the common elements that we saw through the story of one data scientist whose pain really represents kind of
this whole picture so I'm going to introduce Sonia who is building some
sentiment analysis models for the marketing team essentially the marketing team just wants to know how is Netflix
content being perceived on social media so Sonia sets to work and you know at a
high level she needs to you know build her model get a data set to feed the
model and then she needs to figure out how to plug the model into that valuable system that the marketing team is using
so she sets to work um in a way that you know data scientists might typically start their
work she wants to prototype something maybe with a small data set to see if
it's going to work so she opens up her Notebook on her development machine and starts typing
away and and then she reaches a point where hey this might be something that works
but she needs to in order to get a model that's going to work she needs to try many different things different features
different hyper parameters possibly even different model architectures
and so she needs to have a history of her experiment and she comes up with a
rudimentary versioning system where essentially she takes a Jupiter notebook
that worked she copies and pastes it into another Jupiter notebook and changes the suffix with a number so she
has her own makeshift versioning system works for her but you know you might guess that that doesn't necessarily work
in a larger organization at scale so let's so she reaches the point where
she has a model in her notebook that she likes and then she runs into her next problem it's like well how do I get this
notebook to run in the Marketing System she has to dive into their code
um maybe even write her own flask app to host this model behind a rest service
this really takes Sonia out of her way several weeks that she wasn't really
planning on and then to make matters worse in order to train her model reliably at scale
it's not all going to fit on her development machine with her notebook so she needs to work with the
containerized compute cluster that Netflix provides it's called Titus but
it's a lot like kubernetes so if you know kubernetes I'm going to just refer to it as such
so Sonia has to go read the documentation she has to figure out how
do I write a custom executor and how do I distribute my work on this again more
weeks down the drain but she also needs orchestration because
her modeling pipeline has multiple steps and any of those steps can fail they can
run on different machines they need some kind of coordination and so again she has to learn how to get this machine
learning pipeline mapped to the job scheduler that does that orchestration as you can imagine now months have gone
by so a project that Sonia thought was going to take a few a couple of weeks
now has taken four months so stepping back
what we saw after talking to many many data scientists like Sonia is that they
have some common problems that we need to solve and we can start to conceptualize those by looking at them
as this pieces of this machine learning stack all data scientists need data to feed
their model and to flow through their modeling pipeline all of them at one point or another run up with issues
where they need access to Greater compute resources they all need some way to orchestrate their pipelines deal with
failures Etc and they need to version those models
deploy them and of course at the top of the stack we have the actual modeling piece which Sonia thought she was going
to be spending her time on but she didn't get to spend much time so when we looked at this whole stack and we looked at the stories of the data
scientists there was really a key observation behind this which is most of
the time that data scientists were spending was at the bottom of the stack whereas the things they care about are
at the top of the stack we saw this as an opportunity to build
infrastructure and remove some of that heavy lifting that data scientists were doing
and that was the essential concept behind metaflow which takes all of these
layers of the stack and packages them together in a neat abstraction such that
the data scientists don't need to worry about the infrastructure so I'm going to walk you through
metaflow it's going to be a very brief and incomplete tour but there's going to
be some resources you can look at to learn a lot more and we're going to look at metaflow through the lens of this
stack so at its core meta flow essentially
allows you to specify a pipeline as a
dag or a directed acyclic graph of computation and each computation step as
you might expect takes in some data performs some computation and then
produces some more data for output so this is about the simplest flow we can write it has a start step and an end
step and the way that you specify the start step and end step is actually extending this class called flow spec
which is provides you with a bunch of metaflow magic and that allows you to decorate
individual methods with this step decorator to say all the computation
happening in that method is actually a node in the Dag and then you can take the self.next
calls here in order to draw the arrows in between the nodes so with this very
simple construct you can create sort of arbitrarily arbitrarily complex directed
acyclic graphs the other benefit of meta flow is that it will orchestrate all these steps for
you and you can essentially run this class on your local development machine
as if it's just any other python class so there's really you know it provides kind of some nice abstractions here
so let's look at how meta flow helps across the stack and the first thing Sony needs to do is
make sure that her data flows through her pipeline So Meta flow will automatically take any
data that you put into a local class variable and serialize it into a
immutable artifact store and that's a very powerful thing because it
eliminates some decisions and some extra work that Sonia would otherwise have to
do right she no longer has to decide well what format should I serialize this
in you know where should I store it how should I organize it how do I rehydrate
this data how do I handle the failures and the other thing it also helps her
avoid is worrying about well when I am experimenting and there's
new data that I want to look at she doesn't have to remember to go and serialize that data so she might be
adding new model evaluation metrics along the way and they're automatically
handled for her moving up the stack there's also a pretty nice abstraction
for a containerized for running a given step on a containerized compute cluster so this decorator shows how to use
kubernetes to ask for a large memory instance you can do the same thing you know to ask for CPU or GPU resources so
now all of a sudden Sonia can essentially treat kubernetes as a
virtually in virtually infinite extension of her development machine to
provide more resources so as needed she can ask for resources for these memory
or computationally intensive steps meta flow as I mentioned provides
orchestration built in it essentially lays out the dag for you knows what
order the steps should be run in and then runs them where they need to be run whether they're in your local
environment or on your compute cluster you can also use metaflow to map the
flow onto your production schedule or using a simple command line so it can
map onto some onto Argo for example and then as I mentioned before
versioning is built into metaflow and there's just one more important feature
right about these local variables that are put into the medical artifact store they're stored as immutable artifacts
and automatically versioned so every time you run a flow you get a new unique
run ID for that flow so for that run so you can say in the metaflow client API you can later
retrieve that data and say for the hello flow run ID number 10 please get me the
value of x at the start step and you will get the value of one you can also say please get me the value
of x at the end step and you'll get the value of 2. so this is lays the foundation for some pretty important
capabilities that folks like Sonya need for example she can take any given run
and tag it so rather than having to copy and paste her whole notebook she can kind of keep track of her experiments
using tags and tags can also be used to do things like production deployments
keep track of you know which version of the model is in production
and then finally we have deployment Sonia needs to make sure that she can
deploy her model and run it on a schedule most models will get trained on
some frequency and so she can provide this metadata to say hey scheduler please run this flow on a nightly basis
and then finally modeling this is where Sonia has the maximum degrees of freedom
and control without necessarily being constrained to use a particular modeling
framework so at this point she's using scikit-learn and she's requesting a
conda dependency for a specific version of scikit-learn that's very important
because um you know what we don't want to do is sort of have things happen transparently
or unbeknownst to the Sonia we don't want her to worry about hey there was a container running that
some other engineer was managing that you have no idea about and the person managing that container updated your
version of pandas and that updated version of pandas then broke your entire
you know flow so she has some fine rain control over what modeling Frameworks and what version she uses and this
provides a lot of stability we talked about the code a lot and the
reality is though that the code itself doesn't really provide a lot of value
the code needs to be connected to underlying infrastructure for this whole
system to work and that's really the beauty of metaflow it really provides
the glue and abstraction for this entire stack of infrastructure so that data scientists don't have to learn about
each individual piece we'll use an AWS deployment as an example so the artifact
store is deployed and and works on S3 the compute cluster could either be
kubernetes cluster or AWS batch versioning and orchestration are
built-in capabilities of metaflow and then for deployment we can go up using Argo or step functions and then at the
modeling layer we can take advantage of the entire python machine learning
ecosystem so with infrastructure we have you know a pretty powerful setup with
metaflow let me take a couple minutes and talk about zooming back out from the
individual data scientist to like Netflix as a business what impact did
metaflow have here and there were three main concerns the first was velocity data scientists
didn't want to spend months you know deploying their machine learning models the next one was volume Netflix was
doing more and more machine learning not less so we needed to make it easier to do many more applications and then the
third is variety right we're deploying machine learning all the way from maybe
some simple linear models to some complicated computer vision models you
know for media machine learning now for velocity we actually had a
pretty dramatic result if we look at this time to production for the models
that ended up in production they got deployed in a week or less two-thirds of
the time so that that made a huge difference for folks like Sonia
and then when it comes to volume um I want to point out this chart is extremely old so pay more attention to
the shape of this curb we got this hockey stick curve of adoption this is
significant because Netflix doesn't mandate um folks to use a given technology they
have choices and so seeing the choice of metaflow was was really important so now there's thousands of projects running on
metaflow I believe there are over a billion steps that have been run across
all those projects and at Peak we've been able to run over a 10 000 tasks so
the scale is there now in comes when it comes to variety we
didn't actually stop at serving the needs of Netflix we actually had a hypothesis that if we could create a
virtual team of data scientists at many other companies that they would push metaflow in directions that Netflix
wasn't so three years ago we open sourced metaflow and in those years
we've gained adoption of nearly 2 000 community members who are part of the the slack channel it's one of the top 10
open source projects that Netflix has produced I'm proud of this because we're comparing ourselves to famous projects
like chaos monkey and we've also now have multiple Cloud
Integrations Netflix itself is only interested in AWS Integrations but
thanks to open sourcing we have these Integrations with Azure and gcp
and in fact there's a startup called outer bounds that two x Netflix
Engineers went on to found who worked on metaflow and they are focusing on

I kind of touched on in this talk into much more depth in this book so if you
want to learn about applying a data science infrastructure at your company this is definitely the book for you
so we're going to switch gears a bit and talk about the team behind metaflow
Villa in fact is a very friendly person and on my first day at Netflix in 2018
he greeted me very warmly hey Julie yesterday we released metaflow 1.0 and
I'm going to give a talk about meta flow so he led me into the conference room it
was a bit intimidating it was a big room with gladiator style seating and there was already about 70 people from the
data platform in that room and to be honest you know when I sat down I was
expecting to hear a very technical talk to hear about metaflow architecture and
maybe some big fancy numbers about what it could do at scale I had this idea about pla what makes a
successful platform that Ville I'll say fundamentally changed my mind about in
this talk he started with the story of the data
scientists and it wasn't unlike the story I just told you about Sonia
and he also talked about how meta flow made Sonia's life better
so I walked away from that talk realizing that enabling a business to do bigger and
better things at higher scale maybe a nice side effect of a strong platform
but in essence the success of the platform is only as far as the superpowers you
can give the humans that are using that platform and I think the idea that Villa was
embodying in that talk in a lot of his work was this mindset around customer
obsession and I took that mindset very seriously and built and hired the team around this
mindset because honestly I think it was the single most important factor that
led to metaflow being successful so I'm going to spend a few minutes talking about what customer Obsession
and action really looks like and I'll break it down into two main parts
the first is become an expert in your customer needs and I say needs because I
don't mean what they want or what they say would be a nice idea really you need to be the foremost
expert in your customers first you got to choose who your customers are
you actually do have a choice um you cannot you if you think about who your customers are and who they are
it'll actually give you a lot better focus and then you need to spend a lot of time
make it your business to know your customers well if you do this right then the next bit
of it really feels like magic it feels like you're equipping your
customers with superpowers and you do this first by taking away their pain
and you can take you can do this now because you're an expert in their experience you know what their pain is
and once you've done that you've gained their trust and respect and they'll
start to listen to you and then you can start to teach them how to avoid pain in the first place and
that really is Magic so how did this play out in metaflow well the first step was who are our
customers I'll admit that for metaflow in particular this was actually very easy
because we had data scientists literally asking for platform support
so we identified our customers as data scientists as well as machine learning
Engineers not it's not true at all companies but at Netflix data scientists were in charge of the end-to-end machine
learning life cycle so they had to support their models in production as well so really ml engineering is
included but it was equally important enough for us to remind ourselves who our customers
were not there was another type of machine learning practitioner at Netflix called algorithm engineers and they worked on
all the personalization algorithms you see in the member homepage they already had an infrastructure team
supporting them and they were working on the Java stack which is the where the Netflix ecosystem is deployed so we were
just really careful not to focus on their feedback to really inform our strategy and there were some other data
practitioners that we also identified as non-customers so by doing this we would we were able
to come up with a strategy that may seem pretty obvious now but it was actually a
bit controversial right we had this strategy where we started building infrastructure at the bottom of our
stack and worked our way up but conventional wisdom from talking to
many large tech companies that have ml infrastructure teams they were actually solving problems at the top of the stack
so they were doing things like you know building a generic feature store building a model registry or training
framework and instead we focused on some very basic things like you know data
parallel training job scheduling orchestration so knowing who our customers were kind
of gave us that direction and that velocity and that confidence that we
were focusing on the right things and once we identified who our customers
were we now needed to get to know them and there's a few steps that you need to
do to really get to know who your customers are the first is talk to as many of them as
possible in detail about their daily lives I'll say Ville
was quite good at doing this he really focused in on specific examples as
opposed to General statements so hey you know tell me about the last time that you built a feature engineering pipeline
you know what tools did you use what tools did you evaluate where did things
break down what workarounds did you employ you know why did they matter
um so so so framing it in terms of the daily life of your customer is extremely
important because it avoids things like General statements or non-committal
statements like well that would be a good idea there's a really great book um called the mom test it's really small
but I linked it up here on the slide and it really talks about how to have user
conversations so I recommend reading that book once we had many many conversations
patterns began to emerge so in the case of Sonia and many other data scientists
we saw a huge divide between the development sort of environment and the
containerized compute environment and data scientists were kind of struggling to get between these two
so when we saw that pattern The Next Step was not to go build a solution but
rather to pair with data scientists to make them successful
we chose customers who had representative pain of a larger population
and we focused on two things first how do we make those customers
successful wildly so and then second learning along the way how we need to go
about building a solution to their problem okay so why did we bother with this
and the answer is the experiencing self and the remembering self are actually quite
different when you have a conversation with a customer and you ask them about their daily lives you're activating
their remembering self and that person might forget what all
the decision points were along the way what the pitfalls were that they fell in they're going to tell you more about the
end result and when we pair with data scientists and help make them successful we're
activating the experiencing self who is actually going through every step along
the way of their data science projects so we can watch the data scientists experience their pains and because we're
on that project we are experiencing it ourselves so it's from that place of experience
that we can then start to design a solution so in Sonia's case and for many others
we saw kind of this whole workflow where they were starting on their local
machine and we wanted to meet them where they are let's make sure it's easy to run you know metaflow on your local
development machine but there came a point in time where they needed to tap into this you know
practically infinite compute resources so adding this decorator right in line
with their workflow made it much easier for them to access those resources
and very crucially we needed to design this such that we didn't introduce new
pain along the process so for example asking the user hey you should learn
more about kubernetes you know you should come up with a yaml file that's going to configure your job we knew from
experience that that would be introducing new pain so here's where the fun comes in now
that we have helped solve it for a cup one user two users several several
customers now we can really feel confident that we have a solution that works and we want to start teaching the
whole user population how to avoid pain and there's no better way for that teaching to happen than data scientists
teaching other data scientists so organically we saw that in the machine
learning modeling Forum that the data scientists held monthly they started to add slides to their talks about meta
flow and how meta flow helped them in their projects so that's the best result
you want to see it doesn't always happen that way you actually need to do some marketing
but in the case of metaflow we were very careful about what we marketed and when
we did so because we wanted to make a guarantee that features that we added to the
platform could be supported forever right there's nothing like painstakingly building up trust and respective users
only for the users to adopt the features and then immediately things get broken
because there's a breaking change because there's a migration because of system instability so we really took
seriously that anything we advertise had already been tested and proven and
rigorously so and that we could be confident that we would support that for
all time essentially and the other thing that for this particular set of customers is they're not Engineers right
so asking them to do things like migrations wasn't quite reasonable
there was a couple other modalities where we helped customers avoid pain we
provided a slack Channel you know it's kind of the typical support Channel but we really emphasize this idea of
fanatical customer support and the way I could describe that is a helpful
empathetic place where data scientists could ask any questions and feel like
they didn't just get an answer to their question but they got their problem solved and
you know we got a lot of the typical you know technical questions how do I use this oh this thing went wrong
but something funny started to happen we started to get questions that were
more forward-looking over time questions like this this example this is actually
in the metaflow public Channel and the question this person is asking is okay well I'm about to design my flows like
what are some best practices for separating out you know the ETL portion from the training portion how do I do
that in this case Billy actually responded with a couple of helpful articles but but here's an example where
you know we were able to help a customer avoid pain in the first place
one other aspect that I would consider to be part of the product is education
right the engineering team took education seriously and didn't just
treat it as an afterthought and there was a few modalities that were
supported the first one is an example on the left from the metaflow.org documentation and you know if you go and
check out metaflow.org you'll notice that the titles of these articles are
really geared toward the data scientists journey and what they're trying to accomplish as opposed to being a list of
features so for example how do you execute a remote task or how do you
scale up your system and then tutorials is also another method mechanism like showing a complete
end-to-end example and really be really stressed doing that in a fashion that
would be both accessible and relatable to real world problems so in the middle here these tutorials are actually some
more recent ones from Outer bounds they're fantastic definitely recommend you check them out
and then within Netflix we also taught classes this was a great chance to get
data scientists onboarded but also to have conversations with them coming in
what is their impression of metaflow and then what tools they're used to using at
other companies so in some way that was kind of market research that we did
so stepping way back this idea of customer Obsession and this
mindset would be the one thing I would replicate if I were to build a new team
that was building a new product because I do think it's the single biggest reason why meta flow succeeded
one thing to note about customer obsession is that it's a different way to think
about product management in fact you're not really thinking about the product much you're really thinking
about the customer and how you can solve their pain if you do that the product
will follow from them so I hope that provides you with some takeaways for your projects I'd be really interested
